newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SIMEX Euroyen, JGBs off lows but still weak.
newsitem.headline: SIMEX Euroyen, JGBs off lows but still weak.

text.p: SIMEX Euroyen and Japanese government bond (JGB) futures were off their lows in late Friday trade after a technically-driven sell-off earlier.
Sentiment remained very weak on growing expectations of a U.S. interest rate hike at next week's Federal Reserve policy-setting meeting, dealers said.
This expectation was fuelled after Fed chief Alan Greenspan repeated on Thursday the need for the central bank to be pre-emptive in its fight against inflation.
"What's not helped is that the Fed is leaning towards a pre-emptive tightening. Greenspan had it written all over his forehead last night," said a trader with a European house.
"I have a suspicion they'll raise it by 25 basis points, which of course puts pressure on the dollar/yen. But I don't see Japan hiking rates to defend the yen," he added.
December Euroyen was quoted at 98.94 at 1120 GMT after falling as low as 98.89 against an IMM close at 99.03. Volume was an active 31,670 lots.

Dealers said stop-loss sell orders were triggered around 99.01 and then at 98.97. They said the contract looked supported around 98.87/88 but a breach of that area would expose it to further weakness to as far as 98.70/72.

They said there was little fresh news behind the sell-off and players seemed to ignore reports that Moody's Investors Service had downgraded Nippon Credit Bank's bond ratings, a factor that would normally underpin the market.

"We started to see some swap-related selling in Tokyo of a fairly chunky size and that just spooked a thin Euroyen market. Then it was just very technical. There were stops going off all over the place," said the trader.
A Japanese bank dealer said expectations of firmer interest rates in the cash market ahead of the financial year end on March 31 also spurred Euroyen futures sales for hedging.
But he said Euroyen and JGB futures were likely to consolidate and move sideways ahead of the year end and the Bank of Japan (BOJ)'s quarterly tankan on April 2.
June JGBs settled at 125.49 against their previous 126.09.
Eurodollar futures ended slightly little changed in thin trade. Dealers said the market had priced in a 25 basis point rate hike.
June Eurodollars finished at 94.070 against its IMM close at 94.075. September were at 93.830 against 93.825.
